Introduction

An electrocardiogram (ECG) is a critical tool used in the diagnosis of many cardiovascular conditions.  Fundamentally, it is a graph of voltage vs time that tracks electrical activity traveling through the cardiac conduction system (

figure 1
).  A standard 12-lead ECG is collected using (
figure 2
):



  • 6 limb leads (I, II, III, aVL, aVR, aVF), which measure voltages traveling through the frontal (coronal) plane.


  • 6 precordial leads (V1, V2, V3, V4, V5, V6), which measure voltages traveling through the horizontal (transverse) plane.


Measurement of voltages traveling through different areas of the heart facilitates the assessment of rhythm, conduction abnormalities, heart chamber size, and regional myocardial activity.

Cardiac cycle



The typical voltage patterns created during each cardiac cycle are as follows (

figure 3
):



  • The P wave represents atrial depolarization.
  • The PR interval is the period from the beginning of atrial depolarization (start of the P wave) to the beginning of ventricular depolarization.  The duration of the PR interval is primarily determined by the rate of conduction through the atrioventricular (AV) node.  Atrial repolarization occurs during ventricular depolarization and is electrically silent on ECG.
  • The QRS complex represents ventricular depolarization:
    • The Q wave is the initial downward deflection of the QRS complex.
    • The R wave is the first upward deflection of the QRS complex.
    • The S wave is the downward deflection that follows an R wave.
    • Variations in QRS complex morphology and the associated naming conventions are shown here (
      figure 4
      ).
  • The T wave represents ventricular repolarization.
  • The QT interval represents the period from the beginning of ventricular depolarization (start of the Q wave) to the end of ventricular repolarization (end of the T wave), essentially the duration of the ventricular action potential.
  • The ST segment is the period from the end of the S wave to the beginning of the T wave.

Stepwise approach



ECG interpretation is challenging but can be made easier by using a stepwise approach:



  1. Determine the atrial and ventricular rates.
  2. Determine the rhythm.
  3. Determine the axis and intervals.
  4. Assess for atrial and ventricular enlargement.
  5. Evaluate for evidence of ischemia or infarction.
  6. Evaluate for other abnormalities.


Each of these steps is described in detail below.

Rate

Atrial and ventricular rates



The atrial rate is determined by assessing the frequency of P waves and the ventricular rate is determined by assessing the frequency of QRS complexes.  The atrial and ventricular rates are usually the same but may differ when conduction through the AV node is inconsistent (eg, atrial fibrillation, AV block).

Standard ECG grid and rate calculations



A standard ECG grid is composed of large boxes that are 200 msec (0.2 sec) in width.  Each large box is divided into 5 smaller boxes that are 40 msec in width.  A typical ECG strip (recorded at 25 mm/sec) corresponds to a duration of 10 seconds and contains 50 large boxes.  Using these measurements, there are 2 main methods of quickly estimating the ventricular rate using QRS complexes (or atrial rate using P waves) (

image 1
).



  • Method 1:  Number of large boxes between QRS complexes.
    Rate/min = 300/number of large boxes between QRS complexes
    (10 sec = 50 large boxes, so 1 min = 60 sec = 300 large boxes).


  • Method 2:  Total QRS complexes on a standard strip (10 sec).
    Rate/min = total number of QRS complexes Ã— 6
    (because the 10-sec count by 6 gives rate/min).


Examples of these methods for both slow and fast heart rates are shown here (

image 2
,
image 3
).  Method 1 is generally useful only if the rhythm is regular.

Rhythm

Rhythm regularity



There are several categories of rhythm that are based on the regularity of cardiac activity:



  • Regular rhythm:  Activity occurs at consistent, regular intervals.  Sinus rhythm is the fundamental example of regular atrial and ventricular activities (
    image 4
    ).
  • Irregular rhythm:  Activity occurs at variable but at least somewhat predictable intervals.  Ventricular bigeminy is an example of highly predictable, regularly irregular ventricular activity (
    image 5
    ).
  • Irregularly irregular rhythm:  Activity occurs with no discernable pattern.  Atrial fibrillation is the prime example of irregularly irregular ventricular activity (
    image 6
    ).


The rhythm characteristics of common arrhythmias are summarized here (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
).

Sinus rhythm



The first step in rhythm analysis is determining if sinus rhythm is present by confirming the following 3 features:



  • P waves are easily visible.
  • All P waves look the same and occur at regular intervals.
  • All P waves have normal morphology, indicating that they originate in the sinoatrial node and not from another place in the atria.  Normal sinus P waves are upright in leads I and aVF (explained below).


Sinus rhythm at a rate of 60-99/min is considered normal sinus rhythm.



  • Sinus rhythm <60/min is sinus bradycardia.
  • Sinus rhythm â‰¥100/min is sinus tachycardia.

Nonidentical or abnormal P waves



If P waves are easily visible but do not look the same or do not have a normal morphology, consider the following rhythms:



  • An ectopic atrial rhythm is driven by an atrial pacemaker outside the sinoatrial node.  P waves all look the same and occur at regular intervals but do not have normal morphology.  When the atrial rate is â‰¥100/min, this rhythm is referred to as focal atrial tachycardia.


  • Wandering atrial pacemaker involves multiple atrial pacemakers outside the sinoatrial node.  P waves demonstrate â‰¥3 different morphologies and do not occur at regular intervals.  When the atrial rate is â‰¥100/min, this rhythm is referred to as multifocal atrial tachycardia (
    image 7
    ).


  • Atrial flutter results from a reentrant circuit in the atria and demonstrates sawtooth flutter waves occurring at regular intervals (
    image 8
    ).

No P waves



If no P waves are visible, there are 2 possibilities: either there is an absence of organized atrial activity or the P waves are obscured by QRS complexes.



No organized atrial activity



  • Atrial fibrillation is the most common cause of an absence of organized atrial activity.  ECG shows no P waves (only faint fibrillatory waves) and QRS complexes occur at irregularly irregular intervals.


  • Complete sinus node failure can cause an absence of atrial activity.  No sinus P waves are visible and QRS complexes occur at regular intervals due to a distal pacemaker in the AV junction (junctional rhythm) (
    image 9
    ).  Sometimes, retrograde conduction from a junctional rhythm depolarizes the atria and creates inverted (nonsinus) P waves.


P waves obscured by ventricular activity



  • Ventricular tachycardia (VT) is the most common cause of obscured atrial activity.  The atria contract normally (usually driven by sinus rhythm), but ventricular contraction is driven by a separate pacemaker in the ventricles (ie, there are 2 separate pacemakers with atrial-ventricular dissociation).  Wide QRS complexes are present and occur at regular (monomorphic VT) or irregular (polymorphic VT) intervals.  P waves are obscured by the QRS complexes and are rarely visible (
    image 10
    ).


  • Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia is rapid and regular tachycardia with narrow QRS complexes.  AV nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT) (
    image 11
    ) and AV reentrant tachycardia (AVRT) (
    image 12
    ) create retrograde atrial depolarization almost simultaneously with ventricular depolarization, such that P waves are often buried within the QRS complexes and not visible (or are visible just after the QRS complexes).  Other supraventricular tachycardias, when rapid (eg, >150/min), can cause difficulty visualizing P waves; the administration of adenosine may help in identifying the rhythm in such cases (
    figure 5
    ).

Other



  • If P waves are easily visible and have normal morphology but do not occur at regular intervals (ie, sinus pauses and/or sinus arrest are seen), then sinus node dysfunction (eg, sick sinus syndrome) is likely present (
    image 13
    ).
  • If P waves are easily visible, have normal morphology, and occur at regular intervals, but are not consistently followed by a QRS complex, then sinus rhythm with second- or third-degree AV block is present (
    image 14
    ,
    image 15
    ,
    image 16
    ).

Axis and intervals

Axis



The QRS axis is the predominant direction of electrical flow through the ventricles during each contraction.  The positive or negative deflection of voltage in each ECG lead indicates the direction in which electrical current travels in relation to the lead (positive = toward the lead, negative = away from the lead); the voltage deflection of several leads can be aggregated to determine the QRS axis.



A normal QRS axis can usually be determined using the voltage deflections in leads I and aVF.  In the coronal plane, 0Â° is oriented horizontally to the left and, because of the orientation of the heart, the normal QRS axis lies between âˆ’30Â° and +90Â° (

figure 6
).  Leads I and aVF are perpendicular to each other and define the frontal plane: lead I captures left to right (horizontal) vectors (0Â° to 180Â°), and aVF captures up to down (vertical) vectors (âˆ’90Â° to +90Â°).  A positive deflection in a lead means the net depolarization is directed toward that lead's axis.  By determining the sign of the QRS complex in leads I and aVF, the electrical vector can be localized to 1 of 4 quadrants.  Lead II, which lies at +60Â°, is used when additional resolution is needed near the boundary of the normal range.



The QRS axis can be determined using a stepwise approach:



  • If the voltage deflection is positive in leads I and aVF, the QRS axis is between 0Â° and 90Â° and is normal.


  • If the voltage deflection is positive in lead I but negative in lead aVF, the QRS axis is between 0Â° and âˆ’90Â° and could be normal or abnormal.  Further information must be obtained from lead II.

    • If the voltage deflection is positive in lead II, the QRS axis is between 0Â° and âˆ’30Â° and is normal.
    • If the voltage deflection is negative in lead II, the QRS axis is between âˆ’30Â° and âˆ’90Â°and indicates left axis deviation.


  • If the voltage deflection is negative in lead I but positive in lead aVF, the QRS axis is between 90Â° and 180Â° and indicates right axis deviation.


  • If the voltage deflection is negative in leads I and aVF, the QRS axis is between âˆ’90Â° and 180Â°and indicates extreme axis deviation.


The causes of the different types of QRS axis deviation are summarized here (

figure 7
).  The use of voltage deflection in leads I, II, and aVF to determine the QRS axis is summarized here (
ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
).

Intervals



The ECG intervals are indicative of the rates of depolarization, repolarization, and transfer of conduction through the conduction system (

figure 3
).  The normal intervals and conditions that may disrupt these intervals are as follows:



P wave



  • Normal duration:  <120 msec (3 small ECG boxes).
  • Lengthening disruptions:  left atrial enlargement.
  • Shortening disruptions:  none notable.


PR interval



  • Normal duration:  120-200 msec (upper limit 1 large ECG box).
  • Lengthening disruptions (ie, first-degree AV block) (
    image 17
    ):  pharmacologic AV nodal blockers, age-related conduction system degeneration.
  • Shortening disruptions:  Ventricular preexcitation (Wolff-Parkinson-White [WPW] syndrome) (
    image 18
    ).


QRS complex



  • Normal duration:  <120 msec (3 small ECG boxes).
  • Lengthening disruptions:  Bundle branch block, depolarization originating in the ventricles, WPW syndrome.
  • Shortening disruptions:  none notable.


QT interval



  • The corrected QT interval (QTc), which is adjusted for heart rate, should be used.  The QTc is usually estimated automatically on ECG but can be calculated manually using the Bazett formula (
    figure 9
    ).  Normal QTc duration is 350-450 msec in men and 360-460 msec in women.
  • Lengthening disruptions:  Contributors to long QT syndrome (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
    ).
  • Shortening disruptions:  Brugada syndrome, hypercalcemia.


The normal intervals and disruptors of each interval are summarized here (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 4
).  In addition to the disruptors mentioned so far, most antiarrhythmic drugs disrupt ECG intervals (
ðŸ“Š View Table: table 5
).

Bundle branch blocks



Bundle branch blocks involve slowed conduction through the left or right bundle branch.  Because the ventricles are no longer depolarizing simultaneously, bundle branch blocks create a widened QRS complex and can be recognized by characteristic findings in leads V1 and V6, reflecting the direction and sequence of delayed depolarization (

figure 10
).



Left bundle branch block (left ventricle is activated late) is recognized by the following findings in leads V1 and V6:



  • V1:  Deep and wide (broad) S wave.
  • V6:  Wide R wave with notching or slurring and T wave inversion.


Because the impulse travels first down the right bundle branch, the septum depolarizes right to left (which is reversed from normal).  Lead V1, facing the septum, experiences a deep negative deflection (broad S wave) because the initial vector is now moving away.  Meanwhile, lead V6 captures the delayed, slow left ventricular depolarization heading toward it, producing a broad, notched R wave.



Right bundle branch block (right ventricle is activated late) is recognized by the following findings in leads V1 and V6:



  • V1:  Wide QRS complex with RSR' (bunny ears) configuration and T wave inversion.
  • V6:  Wide QRS complex with slurred S wave.


Because the left ventricle depolarizes normally, the initial portion of the QRS complex appears normal.  However, the delayed right ventricular activation produces a second upward deflection (Râ€²) in lead V1 (which faces the right ventricle) and a slurred S wave in lead V6 (which faces the lateral left ventricle) because the electrical forces at the end of depolarization are directed away from the leads.

Chamber enlargement

Atrial enlargement



Atrial enlargement affects atrial depolarization and is recognized by alterations in P wave width and/or height in leads V1 and II.  Conduction through the right atrium creates the initial portion of the P wave and conduction through the left atrium creates the terminal portion of the P wave (

figure 11
).



  • Right atrial enlargement is recognized by the increased height of the P wave in leads V1 and II.
  • Left atrial enlargement is recognized by the increased width and slightly increased height of the terminal portion of the P wave in leads V1 and II (bifid P wave in lead II).

Ventricular enlargement



Ventricular enlargement is primarily recognized by increased QRS voltage created by myocardial hypertrophy.  It can also induce displacement of the QRS axis.



Left ventricular hypertrophy



Identifying left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) requires an assessment of QRS voltage.  On a standard ECG, each mm in height represents 0.1 mV, such that each large box is 5 mm (0.5 mV) in height.  The rectangle on the left side of the ECG (at the start of the strip) represents 1 mV and is used to calibrate voltage for the strip (on a standard strip, the rectangle is 2 large boxes [10 mm] in height).  LVH creates high QRS voltage in the lateral leads (I, aVL, V3-V6), which are closest to the left ventricle.



Many criteria have been developed to define LVH; one of the most common and easiest to use is the Cornell criteria, which defines LVH as follows:



  • In men, R wave height in aVL + S wave height in lead V3 >28 mm (5.6 large boxes in height on a standard ECG).
  • In women, R wave height in aVL + S wave height in lead V3 >20 mm (4 large boxes in height).


An ECG demonstrating LVH via the Cornell criteria is shown here (

image 19
).  LVH commonly creates left axis deviation.  It also commonly creates repolarization abnormalities (eg, ST depression, T wave inversion) in the lateral leads.



LVH may also be recognized by high-voltage S waves in lead V1 or V2 and high-voltage R waves in the far lateral leads (V5 and V6) as shown here (

image 20
).  These findings are consistent with the Sokolow-Lyon criteria for LVH:  S wave in lead V1 or V2 + R wave in lead V5 or V6 >35 mm (7 large boxes in height).



Right ventricular hypertrophy



RVH creates high voltage in the precordial area because it shifts the heart's electrical vector toward the right anterior chest; it is recognized by:



  • Right axis deviation + high-voltage R waves in lead V1 with R:S height ratio >1.


An ECG demonstrating RVH is shown here (

image 21
).  RVH also commonly creates repolarization abnormalities in the precordial leads.

Ischemic changes



ST-segment elevation



ST-segment elevation is the most specific ECG finding for full-thickness myocardial ischemia/infarction and indicates the need for emergency intervention.  ST-segment elevation is recognized by elevation of the J point above the baseline voltage (

figure 12
).  ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) is confirmed by new ST-segment elevation in â‰¥2 anatomically contiguous leads with the following threshold:



  • >1 mm (0.1 mV) in all leads except V2 and V3.
  • For leads V2 and V3, â‰¥1.5 mm in women, â‰¥2 mm in men age â‰¥40, and â‰¥2.5 mm in men age <40.


The leads demonstrating ST-segment elevation correspond with the area of myocardium affected by ischemia/infarction (

figure 13
).  Anterolateral STEMI is shown here (
image 22
), and inferior STEMI is shown here (
image 23
).



Pathologic Q waves



Pathologic Q waves are deep and wide Q waves that are indicative of scar tissue from a previous myocardial infarction.  Because small Q waves (q waves) are a normal effect of septal depolarization in most leads, the following criteria define pathologic Q waves:



  • Leads V2 and V3:  Q waves of any size are pathologic.
  • All other leads:  Q waves >40 msec (1 small box) in width and 2 mm (2 small boxes) in depth are pathologic.


The leads demonstrating pathologic Q waves generally correspond to the area of myocardium affected by scarring.



ST-segment depression



ST-segment depression is a reliable indicator of myocardial ischemia.  It is measured using the following steps:



  • Identify the J point and move 2 small boxes to the right to find the "J + 80 msec" point.
  • The amount of ST-segment depression is then assessed by measuring the difference in height from the "J + 80 msec" point to the baseline voltage.
  • ST-segment depression >1 mm or 0.1 mV (1 small box) is considered significant.


Unlike ST-segment elevation and pathologic Q waves, the leads demonstrating ST-segment depression do not correspond well with the area of affected myocardium.



T-wave inversions



T-wave inversions are nonspecific findings that may suggest myocardial ischemia or strain.

Other ECG abnormalities



Other ECG abnormalities may suggest a specific diagnosis and can be correlated with the patient's clinical presentation.  Characteristic ECG abnormalities suggestive of a particular diagnosis include:



  • Acute pericarditis characteristically demonstrates diffuse ST-segment elevation and PR-segment depression (
    image 24
    ).


  • Pericardial effusion sometimes creates electrical alternans (
    image 25
    ).


  • Hyperkalemia characteristically presents a progression of ECG changes as the severity of hyperkalemia worsens, culminating in a sine wave that progresses to asystole (
    figure 14
    ).


  • Other electrolyte abnormalities create characteristic ECG findings as shown here (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 6
    ).


  • Brugada syndrome characteristically demonstrates a pseudo right bundle branch block pattern in lead V1 and downward-sloping ST-segment elevation with T-wave inversion in leads V1 and V2 (
    image 26
    ).


  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy commonly demonstrates evidence of LVH with T-wave repolarization abnormalities (
    image 27
    ).


  • WPW syndrome, during normal sinus rhythm, demonstrates delta waves (slurred upstroke of the QRS complex) in addition to a shortened PR interval and a widened QRS complex.

Summary



An electrocardiogram (ECG) is a time-voltage graph that records the heart's electrical activity.  The waveform componentsâ€”P wave, PR interval, QRS complex, ST segment, T wave, and QT intervalâ€”each reflect specific phases of the cardiac cycle.  ECG interpretation should follow a stepwise approach: assessing rate, rhythm, axis, intervals, chamber enlargement, and ischemic or structural abnormalities.  Rate is estimated from QRS or P wave spacing using the ECG grid, whereas rhythm analysis often focuses on the presence, morphology, and regularity of P waves.  Axis determination uses the polarity of leads I and aVF, sometimes aided by lead II.  Intervals reflect conduction timing and are influenced by various pathologies and medications.  Specific patterns can suggest chamber enlargement, bundle branch blocks, ischemia (eg, ST-segment elevation or ST-segment depression, pathologic Q waves), or other diagnoses.
